titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Albert Duveen Collection of Artists' Letters and Ephemera, 1807-1946, in the Archives of American Art AAA.duvealbe
Duveen (Albert) collection of artists' letters and ephemera
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Judy Ng
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

note.p: This finding aid was created from a MARC collection-level record. 209208

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-09-29T11:33-0400

did.unittitle: Albert Duveen collection of artists' letters and ephemera
did.abstract: The Albert Duveen collection of artists' letters and ephemera measures 1.1 linear feet and dates from 1807 to 1946. Unrelated letters written by over 170 mostly 19th and early 20th century American artists are found in this compiled collection of art critic, dealer, and collector Albert Duveen. Additional ephemera includes printed material and photographs of artwork.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Albert Duveen collection of artists' letters and ephemera was purchased from Duveen by the Archives of American Art in February 1956.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The Archives holds a microfilm copy of the Albert Duveen art reference files and a lecture, "An Art Dealer is Intrigued by American Folk Art," delivered by Albert Duveen, March 4, 1961.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: This collection is available on 35 mm microfilm reels DDU1, D9, D10, and NDU-1-5 at the Archives of American Art offices, and through interlibrary loan. Researchers should note that the arrangement of the papers as described in this finding aid does not reflect the order of the collection on microfilm due to reprocessing.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The letters were microfilmed shortly after receipt onto reels DDU1, D9-D10, and NDU-1-5. A finding aid was prepared by Judy Ng in 2013 with funding provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Albert Duveen collection of artists' letters and ephemera, 1807-1946. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Albert Duveen collection of artists' letters and ephemera are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Art critic, collector, and dealer Albert Duveen (1892-1965) lived and worked in New York City, New York. He is known for his expertise in early American art and was a cousin to Joseph Duveen, president of Duveen Brothers art dealers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Albert Duveen collection of artists' letters and ephemera measures 1.1 linear feet and dates from 1807 to 1946. Unrelated letters written by over 170 mostly 19th and early 20th century American artists are found in this compiled collection of art critic, dealer, and collector Albert Duveen. Additional ephemera includes printed material and photographs of artwork.

Found are letters from artists Albert Bierstadt, Frederic E. Church, Frederick S. Church, Henry Inman, Constant Mayer, Jervis McEntee, Henry Mosler, Frederick Law Olmstead, Rembrandt Peale, Albert Rosenthal, and many others. Printed materials include catalog inventories of public and private art collections. There are also brochure booklets on New England historical houses and towns. Photographs are duplicate copies of early American artwork from Duveen's personal reference files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 3 series.

list.item: Series 2: Printed material, circa 1909-1946 (4 folders; Box 1, OV 2)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters are written by over 170 early American artists, including Albert Bierstadt, Frederic E. Church, Frederick S. Church, Constant Mayer, Henry Mosler, Frederick Law Olmsted, Albert Rosenthal, and Anne Whitney. Two letters of interest by Henry Inman and Rembrandt Peale describe opinions on their work and the works of others. There are also letters related to the John Trumbull estate; miscellaneous printed items included with letters; and a selection of letters written by European artists.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Letters are arranged alphabetically by surname followed by letters from foreign and miscellaneous artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material on John Trumbull and the Trumbull estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed materials include catalog inventories of the following public and private art collections: the Bucks County Historical Society, the Lee Museum, J. Horace Harding, William Penn, and George Taylor. There are also brochure booklets on the historical towns of Cooperstown, Greenfield Village, South Haven, Yorktown, and Gloucester.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by document type.

did.unittitle: Oversize Print of Black Stallion from Box 1, Folder 198

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs are duplicate copies of early American artwork from Duveen's personal reference files. These include portraits, cityscapes, landscapes, still lifes, and abstract paintings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by subject matter.
